[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: ledger_db_column_families()] [State corruption] Can an attacker exploit missing or duplicate column family names in the returned vector to cause state divergence between validators, leading to consensus failures when different nodes query inconsistent database schemas? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: ledger_db_column_families()] [Data loss] If the column family list is modified after initial deployment, could existing validators crash or lose access to critical data like TRANSACTION_INFO_CF_NAME or LEDGER_INFO_CF_NAME, causing permanent state loss and network partition? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: ledger_db_column_families()] [Replay attack] Could an attacker manipulate the ordering of column families (especially TRANSACTION_CF_NAME vs TRANSACTION_BY_HASH_CF_NAME) to cause transaction replay vulnerabilities when queries return stale or incorrect transaction data? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: state_merkle_db_column_families()] [Merkle proof forgery] Can an attacker exploit the separation of JELLYFISH_MERKLE_NODE_CF_NAME and STALE_NODE_INDEX_CF_NAME to inject fraudulent Merkle nodes, allowing fabrication of state proofs that validators accept as valid, enabling theft of funds? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: state_merkle_db_column_families()] [Cross-epoch attack] Does STALE_NODE_INDEX_CROSS_EPOCH_CF_NAME properly isolate epoch boundaries, or can an attacker reuse stale Merkle nodes from previous epochs to forge state commitments and create inconsistent state roots across validators? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: state_kv_db_column_families()] [State key collision] Can an attacker craft state keys that cause collisions between STATE_VALUE_CF_NAME and STALE_STATE_VALUE_INDEX_CF_NAME entries, leading to state corruption where current values are overwritten by stale data during pruning operations? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: state_kv_db_new_key_column_families()] [Migration vulnerability] During the transition from old to new key schema (STATE_VALUE_INDEX_CF_NAME still present for backward compatibility), can an attacker exploit inconsistencies between STATE_VALUE_BY_KEY_HASH_CF_NAME and legacy lookups to cause double-spending by reading stale balances? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: state_kv_db_new_key_column_families()] [Hash collision] Does STATE_VALUE_BY_KEY_HASH_CF_NAME use cryptographically secure hashing, or can an attacker generate hash collisions to overwrite arbitrary state values belonging to other accounts, enabling fund theft? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: hot_state_kv_db_column_families()] [Cache poisoning] Can an attacker force frequently accessed state into the HOT_STATE_VALUE_BY_KEY_HASH_CF_NAME through transaction patterns, then manipulate this hot cache to serve incorrect state values to validators during consensus, causing safety violations? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: event_db_column_families()] [Event ordering attack] Can an attacker exploit the separation of EVENT_BY_KEY_CF_NAME, EVENT_BY_VERSION_CF_NAME, and EVENT_CF_NAME to cause event reordering or duplication, breaking smart contract invariants that depend on event sequencing? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: transaction_accumulator_db_column_families()] [Accumulator forgery] Can an attacker inject fraudulent entries into TRANSACTION_ACCUMULATOR_HASH_CF_NAME that are inconsistent with TRANSACTION_ACCUMULATOR_CF_NAME, causing validators to compute different transaction roots and creating a permanent network fork? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: transaction_db_column_families()] [Account indexing attack] Can an attacker exploit ORDERED_TRANSACTION_BY_ACCOUNT_CF_NAME indexing to hide transactions from API queries while they remain in TRANSACTION_CF_NAME, enabling hidden fund transfers that bypass monitoring systems? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: transaction_db_column_families()] [Hash collision DoS] Can an attacker generate transactions with colliding hashes to corrupt TRANSACTION_BY_HASH_CF_NAME index, making legitimate transactions permanently unretrievable and causing user fund loss? [File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: ledger_metadata_db_column_families()] [Epoch manipulation] Can an attacker corrupt EPOCH_BY_VERSION_CF_NAME to cause validators to apply wrong validator sets, allowing unauthorized block proposals and breaking Byzantine fault tolerance assumptions? [File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: ledger_metadata_db_column_families()] [Block metadata forgery] Can an attacker manipulate BLOCK_INFO_CF_NAME independently from BLOCK_BY_VERSION_CF_NAME to cause metadata-block mismatches, leading to incorrect gas calculations or reward distributions? [File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: skip_reporting_cf()] [Monitoring bypass] Does excluding DEFAULT_COLUMN_FAMILY_NAME and DB_METADATA_CF_NAME from reporting allow attackers to hide malicious activity or database corruption in these column families, delaying detection of critical security incidents? [File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: gen_cfds()] [Compression attack] Can an attacker exploit the hardcoded Lz4 compression (line 172) by crafting highly compressible transaction data that expands massively during decompression, causing memory exhaustion and validator crashes during database reads? [File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: gen_cfds()] [Compaction DoS] Does the compact_on_deletion_collector_factory configuration (line 174) with ratio 0.4 allow an attacker to trigger excessive compaction operations through deletion-heavy transaction patterns, degrading validator performance below consensus liveness thresholds? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: gen_cfds()] [Memory exhaustion] Can an attacker cause unbounded memory growth by exploiting the Options::default() initialization (line 171) before compression settings are applied, allowing OOM attacks during database initialization? [File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: gen_cfds()] [Race condition] Is the cf_opts_post_processor function pointer (line 175) thread-safe when called concurrently during database initialization, or can race conditions cause inconsistent column family configurations across shards, leading to state divergence? [File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: gen_cfds()] [Configuration injection] Can an attacker manipulate the RocksdbConfig parameter to inject malicious table_options that override security-critical settings like bloom filters or cache behavior, bypassing intended access controls? [File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: gen_cfds()] [Descriptor overflow] With Vec::with_capacity(cfs.len()) allocation (line 167), can an attacker provide an excessively large column family list causing integer overflow in capacity calculation, leading to heap corruption? [File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: gen_table_options()] [Block size manipulation] Can an attacker exploit the configurable block_size (line 188) by setting extremely small values (e.g., 1 byte) to cause excessive I/O operations, degrading validator performance and potentially causing consensus timeouts and liveness failures? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: gen_table_options()] [Block size overflow] Can block_size be set to values approaching u64::MAX causing integer overflow when RocksDB performs block size calculations, leading to memory corruption or incorrect data reads? (High)

[File: aptos-core/storage/aptosdb/src/db_options.rs] [Function: gen_table_options()] [Cache poisoning] Does the shared block_cache (line 197-199) allow an attacker to pollute the cache with malicious data from one column family that affects reads in other column families, enabling cross-CF state manipulation attacks?
